channel.title: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: Serious Work Begins to Create a Treaty on Crimes Against Humanity
item.description: Afghanistan. Myanmar. Syria. The Democratic Republic of the Congo. Over the last 80 years, there has rarely been a situation of atrocity that has not been marked by the commission of crimes against humanity. These crimes, defined by their widespread or systematic nature, target civilians and devastate societies. Yet, while the international community has created ... Read more

item.title: Guinea-Bissau still debating controversial US hepatitis B vaccine trial
item.description: The director-general of public health from Guinea-Bissau said the country is still examining whether it will move forward with the study.

item.title: Congress may pass a $50B foreign aid bill. Will Trump spend the money?
item.description: Even if Congress passes this budget bill, will the Trump administration spend the money as directed? Experts explored that question in a Devex Pro Briefing.

item.title: UN agencies embrace AI as budgets fall and staff demand rises
item.description: In the face of budget cuts and rising staff demand, United Nations agencies are ramping up efforts to leverage artificial intelligence.

item.title: Scoop: US loses Gavi board seat after withholding funding
item.description: “As the United States government has not yet pledged to Gavi it is currently not on the Gavi Board,” a Gavi spokesperson told Devex.

item.title: Devex CheckUp: Does the US officially bow out of the World Health Organization today?
item.description: Can the United States officially withdraw from WHO without paying its debts? Plus, the Gates Foundation and OpenAI announce $50 million integrate AI into health systems across Africa.

item.title: When can small grants give big value?
item.description: Opinion: Small, flexible grants are not a substitute for larger funding, but by focusing on uptake over immediate outputs, they can be catalytic in driving long-term change, from strengthening capacity to shifting organizational practice.

item.title: Devex Newswire: Hope or hype? One US lawmaker says help is on the way
item.description: U.S. Sen. Chris Coons is optimistic that Congress will pass the $50 billion foreign aid budget bill next week and President Donald Trump will sign it. Plus, tips to start a development job search in 2026, and the inside story on Food for Peace’s transition to USDA.

item.title: At UN, war crimes probe pledges to work for all in Hamas-Israel conflict
item.description: As President Trump launched the international Board of Peace plan for Gaza on Thursday, top independent rights experts tasked by the UN Human Rights Council with investigating grave abuses linked to the Hamas-Israel war pledged to continue their work seeking justice and accountability for all.

item.title: For every $1 spent protecting nature, $30 goes to destroying it
item.description: The world spends billions to protect nature, but trillions are being invested in business activities that harm the environment.

item.title: Syria: Renewed clashes risk derailing fragile transition
item.description: A tense standoff between the Syrian Government and Kurdish-led forces in the country’s northeast risks igniting wider instability just as Syria struggles to emerge from years of conflict and authoritarian rule, senior UN officials told the Security Council on Thursday.

item.title: World News in Brief: Winter attacks in Ukraine, looming food aid cuts in Nigeria, drought in Kenya
item.description: Russian forces launched a fresh wave of strikes across Ukraine this week which have left hundreds of thousands of families without electricity and heating amid freezing temperatures.

item.title: ‘Dangerous nostalgia’ a threat to multilateralism, UN deputy chief tells Danish MPs
item.description: United Nations Deputy Secretary-General Amina Mohammed urged countries to protect the UN Charter in a powerful speech to the Danish Parliament on Thursday, urging countries to “stand up for a rules-based order” – or pay the price.

item.title: UN warns of rising internet shutdowns as digital blackouts spread worldwide
item.description: A rising trend towards government-enforced internet shutdowns – with at least 300 incidents in more than 54 countries over the last two years – is prompting renewed warnings from the UN about the threat these digital blackouts pose to freedom of expression, access to information and human rights.

item.title: Can the US formally withdraw from WHO without paying its debts?
item.description: Paying what’s owed to the organization is one of the conditions of its withdrawal.

item.title: The latest from the World Economic Forum meeting in Davos
item.description: For the latest episode of our weekly podcast series, Senior Editor Rumbi Chakamba sits down with Devex President and Editor-in-Chief Raj Kumar and Global Development Reporter Elissa Miolene to bring you the latest from Davos.

item.title: Sen. Coons expects Senate to pass, Trump to sign $50B aid budget bill
item.description: At the World Economic Forum in Davos, the Democratic senator said he is hopeful that lawmakers will pass — and Trump will sign — a multimillion-dollar foreign aid funding bill currently being discussed on Capitol Hill.

item.title: Why Save the Children US prioritizes donor engagement skills in hiring
item.description: As the organization rebuilds its fundraising teams, its looking for experts with transferable skills to engage new donors.

item.title: Big Nature-Based Finance Turnaround Needed to Restore, Protect Ecosystems
item.description: The world is pouring trillions of dollars each year into activities that destroy nature while investing only a fraction of that amount in protecting and restoring the ecosystems on which economies depend, according to a new United Nations report released on today (January 22). The State of Finance for Nature 2026 report by the United Nations […]

item.title: World’s Oceans Hit Record Heat in 2025, at Great Economic and Social Costs
item.description: In 2025, global ocean temperatures rose to some of the highest levels ever recorded, signaling a continued accumulation of heat within the Earth’s climate system and raising deep concern among climate scientists. The economic toll of ocean-related impacts—including collapsing fisheries, widespread coral reef degradation, and mounting damage to coastal infrastructure—is now estimated to be nearly […]

item.title: Steering Nepal’s Economy Amid Global Challenges
item.description: Nepal has a unique opportunity for transformation. The recent youth-led protests underscored aspirations for greater transparency, governance and a more equal distribution of economic opportunities and resources. This yearning resonated in Nepal and beyond. Now, Nepal must find a balance in setting prudent political, economic and financial policies to steer a difficult transition in an […]
